am.pdf pdf false 1644792 AAM-PDF MCAT 113238 113238 S2468-8231(23)00322-X 10.1016/j.mcat.2023.113238 Fig. 1 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of ZrO2 and ZrO2-supported Mn catalysts synthesized by physical mixing method (Mn+ZrO2) and co-precipitation method (Mn-ZrO2). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the Mn metal, ZrO2, and ZrO2-supported Mn catalysts that were synthesized by the physical mixing method (Mn+ZrO2) and co-precipitation method (Mn-ZrO2). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 FTIR spectra of ZrO2 and ZrO2-supported Mn catalysts synthesized by physical mixing method (Mn+ZrO2) and co-precipitation method (Mn-ZrO2). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Mn 2p core level XPS spectra of ZrO2-supported Mn catalysts synthesized by physical mixing method (Mn+ZrO2) and co-precipitation method (Mn-ZrO2). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Zr 3d core level XPS spectra of ZrO2, ZrO2-supported Mn catalysts synthesized by physical mixing method (Mn+ZrO2) and co-precipitation method (Mn-ZrO2). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 O 1s core level XPS spectra of ZrO2, ZrO2-supported Mn catalysts synthesized by physical mixing method (Mn+ZrO2) and co-precipitation method (Mn-ZrO2). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 SEM-EDS images of Mn-based catalysts Mn+ZrO2 (a-d) and Mn-ZrO2 (e-h): a and e are the EDS images, b and f are SEM images (scale 1 µm), c and g present Zr mapping, and d and h present Mn mapping of Mn+ZrO2 and Mn-ZrO2, respectively. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Comparison of the catalytic activity of Mn, Mn+ZrO2, and Mn-ZrO2 catalysts synthesized by different methods. Operating conditions: catalyst weight = 40 mg, reaction temperature = 225 °C; CO2 pressure = 10 bar; 0.25 M NaOH, 1 mL N2H4·H2O and reaction time 4 h. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Effect of reaction time on CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid and acetic acid with Mn+ZrO2 catalyst synthesized by physically mixed method. Operating conditions: catalyst weight = 40 mg, reaction temperature = 225 °C; CO2 pressure = 10 bar; 0.25 M NaOH, 1 mL N2H4·H2O. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Effect of change in CO2(initial) pressure on CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid and acetic acid with Mn+ZrO2 catalyst synthesized by physically mixed method. Operating conditions: catalyst weight = 40 mg, reaction temperature = 225 °C; 0.25 M NaOH (in 50 mL of water); and 0.4 M N2H4·H2O (1 mL of hydrazine monohydrate) and reaction time 6 h. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Effect of weight of the catalyst on CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid and acetic acid with Mn+ZrO2 catalyst synthesized by physically mixed method. Table 1 Catalyst SSA (m2/g) Total pore volume (cm3/g) Average pore diameter (nm) ZrO2 175 0.113 2.6 Mn+ZrO2 158 0.106 2.7 Mn-ZrO2 191 0.140 2.9 Effective production of formic and acetic acid via CO2 hydrogenation with hydrazine by using ZrO2 catalysts Tatiparthi Vikram Sagar Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Praveen Kumar Investigation Writing – review & editing a Boštjan Žener Investigation Formal analysis a Andraž Šuligoj Writing – review & editing a Kamila Kočí Writing – review & editing b Urška Lavrenčič Štangar Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Supervision a a Faculty of Chemistry and Chemical Technology, University of Ljubljana, Večna pot 113, Ljubljana 1000, Slovenia Faculty of Chemistry and Chemical Technology University of Ljubljana Večna pot 113 Ljubljana 1000 Slovenia aFaculty of Chemistry and Chemical Technology, University of Ljubljana, Večna pot 113, Ljubljana 1000, Slovenia b Institute of Environmental Technology, VŠB-Technical University of Ostrava, 17. listopadu 15/2172, Ostrava 70800, Czech Republic Institute of Environmental Technology VŠB-Technical University of Ostrava 17. listopadu 15/2172 Ostrava 70800 Czech Republic bInstitute of Environmental Technology, VŠB-Technical University of Ostrava, 17. listopadu 15/2172, Ostrava 70800, Czech Republic ⁎ Corresponding author. Amorphous ZrO2 and Mn addition to ZrO2 catalysts were studied for CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid and acetic acid via an indirect hydrogen source, i.e., hydrazine monohydrate. The amorphous ZrO2 was synthesized by the precipitation method and the Mn addition was carried out by two different methods, namely, the physical mixing method (Mn+ZrO2) and the co-precipitation method (Mn-ZrO2). The XRD and XPS results show that the enhanced metal-support interaction in the co-precipitation method leads to the stabilization of Mn in its higher oxidation state. The physical mixing method leads to the stabilization of Mn in its lower oxidation state and/or metallic form, which improves hydrogen production from hydrazine and thus CO2 hydrogenation. Optimization of reaction parameters was investigated with changes in reaction conditions such as reaction time, CO2 pressure and catalyst weight. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 utilization Formic acid Acetic acid CO2 hydrogenation Hydrazine Mn-based catalysts Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide emission is increasing enormously compared to other greenhouse gasses contributing to global warming and temperature rise [1]. Global warming is driving the scientific community to initiate different routes for mitigating CO2 emissions [1,2]. CO2 is a highly available and potential source of C1 chemistry. The conversion of CO2 is gaining attention day by day, the important reactions are reduction, hydrogenation, and oxidation reactions to high value-added products such as syngas, formic acid, methane, higher hydrocarbons, methanol, dimethyl ether, ethene, etc. [2–14]. CO2 to value-added products is an advantageous process as well as highly challenging because CO2 is a highly stable molecule, the thermal activation of CO2 requires severe reaction conditions like elevated temperatures and/or pressures. Of all the CO2 conversion routes, most studies in recent years have focused on the reduction of CO2 to methane, methanol, formic acid, and acetic acid [15,16]. Formic acid production via CO2 hydrogenation has attracted a great deal of interest due to its wide range of use in many industrial applications such as agricultural, leather and dye industries [17,18]. CO2 hydrogenation can be accomplished in many different ways, and the use of direct hydrogen for CO2 hydrogenation is a popular and widely demonstrated route for important value-added products. Hydrogen is a commonly used product for several important applications in the energy sector and chemical industry. Also, hydrogen is considered a forthright solution to the pollution and global warming related to energy and power generation. The hydrogen demand is expected to increase in a few decades. So, CO2 hydrogenation via an indirect hydrogen source is an atom economy reaction where the produced hydrogen can be used instantly for the hydrogenation reaction. Several researchers studied CO2 hydrogenation via indirect hydrogen sources. Electrochemical reduction, photocatalytic reduction, and hydrothermal reduction have been carried out in recent years [19–28]. The hydrothermal reduction of CO2 is carried out by using an indirect source of hydrogen produced by water splitting and decomposition of hydrazine with catalysts (Fe, Al, Zn, and Mn) [29]. In these hydrothermal reductions of CO2, many researchers used NaHCO3 as a CO2 source while direct use of CO2 in hydrothermal reduction is less practiced. The hydrogen storage materials like glucose, glycerol and hydrazine are utilized as an indirect source of hydrogen for CO2 reduction [30–32]. Hydrogen storage materials are advantageous in the hydrogen economy society. One such important material is hydrazine. In its anhydrous form, hydrazine is in the liquid phase at ambient temperature and is highly flammable as well as explosive when exposed to metal due to its high amount of hydrogen (12 wt.%). Direct utilization of anhydrous hydrazine is highly dangerous and not recommended. Therefore, the monohydrated hydrazine (H2NNH2·H2O) has attracted more attention due to the large hydrogen capacity of 7.9 wt.%, it is less explosive and safe to use. The complete decomposition of monohydrated hydrazine liberates H2 and N2 as products. So, monohydrate hydrazine is a suitable material for the hydrothermal reduction of CO2 [32–34]. The utilization of hydrazine as a hydrogen source for hydrothermal CO2 reduction was extensively studied by Jin et al. with NaHCO3 as a CO2 source employing different metals like Ni, Fe, Cu, Co and Al-Ni alloy as catalysts [29,32]. Hydrothermal CO2 reduction is also carried out by water splitting with metals, metal/metal oxides and multi-metallic catalysts [18,23–25,29,35–40]. The highly active metals for the hydrothermal reduction of CO2 to formic acid are Mn>Al=Cu>Ni>Fe [29]. However, the reaction is performed with NaHCO3 as a CO2 source and in-situ generated H2 via water splitting. The metal/metal oxide-based catalytic systems were also studied for hydrothermal reactions of CO2 reduction to formic acid, the important catalysts are Zn/ZnO and Fe/FeOx [29,38,40,41]. The H2 adsorption is enhanced with the coexistence of metal/metal oxide species which in turn enhances the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid. The metal and metal oxide interface plays a vital role in improving the formic acid yield. Notable multi-metallic catalysts are CuAlZn, Ni/Fe, and Cu/Fe; the metal ratios are important, where using a high amount of Cu leads to formic acid decomposition [32,38,40,42]. On the other hand, the metal hydride intermediate leads to improving the formic acid yield. In our recent work, CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over Au-based ZrO2 catalysts showed promising activity[43]. So, a catalyst with non-noble metal was developed with amorphous ZrO2 as support. In this study, CO2 hydrogenation to formic and acetic acid via an indirect hydrogen source was performed on novel Mn-based ZrO2 catalysts synthesized by two methods, physical mixing and co-precipitation. The catalysts were characterized using various physicochemical techniques. The improved catalytic activity via surface modification with the addition of Mn on amorphous ZrO2 support by different methods was the main focus. The novelty of this work is the development of a novel catalytic system of Mn and ZrO2 support and the use of pure CO2 gas for CO2 hydrogenation to formic and acetic acid via an indirect hydrogen source. The optimization of reaction conditions was carried out by different conditions like reaction time, CO2 initial pressure and weight of the catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 Synthesis of ZrO2 support ZrO2 support was synthesized with a similar approach as in our recent report [43]. In short, zirconium(IV) oxynitrate (ZrO(NO3)2·xH2O, p.a., Aldrich) was dissolved in ultrapure water and precipitated with dropwise addition of aqueous ammonia. After complete precipitation, the support was aged in an oven for 24 h at 80 °C in air. The white precipitate after filtration was dried overnight at 90 °C. The obtained powder was further well-ground and calcined at 300 °C for 4 h in static air with a heating ramp of 10 °C/min. Later, the catalyst was reduced at 350 °C for 2 h in 5% H2 balanced Ar flow with a heating ramp of 10 °C/min. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Mn+ZrO2 by physical mixing A calculated amount of Mn metal powder was added to the prepared ZrO2 support and ground physically in a mortar and pestle in a periodic fashion until both solids were uniformly mixed (for approximately 5 min of grounding with two cycles of 2.5 min). The catalyst with physical mixing is named Mn+ZrO2, the amount of Mn in the solid is 6 wt.%. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Mn-ZrO2 by co-precipitation 6 wt.% Mn-ZrO2 was synthesized by the co-precipitation method using zirconium(IV) oxynitrate (ZrO(NO3)2·xH2O, p.a., Aldrich), manganese nitrate (Mn(NO3)3·6H2O, p.a., Merck) and aqueous ammonia as the precipitating agent. After complete precipitation, the solution with white precipitate was aged in an oven for 24 h at 80 °C in air. The white precipitate after filtration was dried overnight at 90 °C. The obtained powder was further well-ground and calcined at 300 °C for 4 h in static air with a heating ramp of 10 °C/min. Later, the catalyst was reduced at 350 °C for 2 h in 5% H2 balanced Ar flow with a heating ramp of 10 °C/min. The catalysts synthesized by the co-precipitation method are designated as Mn-ZrO2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore diameter of the synthesized catalysts were determined by using the BET/BJH method with N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. These analyses were carried out on 3P sync 200 instruments. Before the measurements, in-situ degassing of the samples was carried out by 3P-sync TC 208Smart-Prep degasser in N2 gas at 120 °C for 1 h. Total pore volume and pore size were calculated by the BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) method from the desorption isotherms. XRD studies of all the supports and catalysts were carried out on the PANalytical Empyrean diffractometer using Bragg-Brentano geometry with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å). The measurements were recorded in a stepwise increment of 0.045° with a count time of 0.5 s and in a 2θ range from 10 to 80° X'Pert High Score Plus software was used to analyze the crystalline phases of support and catalysts. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis was carried out by using Perkin Elmer Spectrum 100 instrument, using the KBr pellet method. The analyses were performed in the range between 4000 and 400 cm−1. XPS measurements were performed using a PHI VersaProbe III (Version AD) (PHI, Chanhassen, USA) equipped with a hemispherical analyzer and a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source. Survey spectra were measured using a pass energy of 224 eV and step of 0.8 eV/s. The catalyst morphology and elemental mapping were conducted with SEM-EDS (scanning electron microscopy- energy dispersive spectroscopy) by using Zeiss ULTRA Plus instrument equipped with INCA EDS detector. 2.3 Activity tests The CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid and acetic acid activity tests were conducted in a high-pressure Teflon-coated batch reactor with a total volume of 280 mL placed in a thick stainless-steel autoclave (BTC 3000) supplied by Berghof Ltd., Germany. 0.25 M NaOH solution was prepared and CO2 gas was continuously purged through the solution until saturated. 40 mg of a catalyst was added to 50 mL of CO2-dissolved NaOH solution and 0.4 M N2H4·H2O mixture (1 mL of hydrazine monohydrate added in 50 mL of the reaction mixture), then sealed and pressurized with 10 bar of pure CO2 gas. The reactor vessel was placed in a heating brick supplied by Berghof, and the heating brick was already heated to 225 °C. After 4 h of reaction, the resulting solution has been collected by centrifugation and analyzed with an HPLC apparatus (Agilent-1260 Infinity II) equipped with Rezex™ ROA-Organic Acid H+ column using UV detector set at 210 nm. The mobile phase consisted of 0.005 N H2SO4 with a flow of 0.05 mL/min. The outlet solution has two main products, namely formic acid (FA) and acetic acid (AA). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Specific surface area The specific surface area was determined by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of catalysts and is depicted in Fig. 1 . The isotherms resemble a type-I isotherm attributed to the microporous materials. The H1-type hysteresis loop observed in the isotherms signifies that the porous materials contain cylindrical-like pore channels and/or agglomerates of uniform spheres [43,44]. Table 1 shows the summarized specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore diameter of catalysts. All the catalysts exhibit high specific surface areas of 175, 158, and 191 m2/g for ZrO2, Mn+ZrO2, and Mn-ZrO2, respectively. The support exhibited a high surface area of 175 m2/g and the metal addition by physical mixing (Mn+ZrO2) showed a slight decrease in surface area due to the pore blockage. The pore volume of the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst is 0.106 cm3/g and of the ZrO2 support is 0.113 cm3/g. The decrease in pore volume signifies the pore blockage by metal addition in the physical mixing method. On the contrary, the co-precipitated Mn-ZrO2 catalyst showed an increase in the surface area from 175 to 191 m2/g, and the pore volume of Mn-ZrO2 increased to a volume of 0.140 cm3/g. Similar results were observed in our recent work with MnO2-modified CeO2 catalysts, where the addition of metal by co-precipitation increases the specific surface area [45]. The enhanced pore volume and the metal-support interactions developed during the synthesis process may lead to improving the specific surface area of the catalysts. 3.1.2 X-ray powder diffraction analysis The crystallographic phase composition of the catalysts was analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction and presented in Fig. 2 . ZrO2 support showed broad peaks at 2θ = ∼30 and ∼50° that were ascribed to the amorphous ZrO2 [43,46–48]. X-ray pattern of Mn metal (supplied by Merck, Germany) showed intense diffraction peaks at 2θ = 43.0, 47.8, 50.0, 52.3, 73.5, 75.3 and 78.8°, which were attributed to the cubic phase of metallic Mn (JCPDS card # 00–020–0180). The physical mixing of Mn catalyst (i.e., Mn+ZrO2) showed diffraction peaks at 2θ = 43.0, 47.8, 50.0, 52.3 and 78.8°, which match the Mn cubic phase, while broad peaks at 2θ = ∼30 and ∼50° signify that the ZrO2 was in its amorphous phase. The co-precipitated Mn-ZrO2 catalyst showed only two broad peaks related to amorphous ZrO2. Although the same amount of Mn was added in this case, no diffraction peaks correlated with Mn metal are observed. The absence of Mn metallic peaks may be due to the precursor used for the co-precipitation method which is Mn-nitrate, on the other hand, the precursor for the physical mixing method is the direct use of metal. Also, the absence of Mn peaks in the co-precipitation method is maybe due to the formation of Mn nanoparticles and/or the metal-support interactions that might lead to the oxidation of Mn. 3.1.3 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy Fig. 3 shows the FTIR spectra with vibrational bands in the range of 4500–400 cm−1, which exhibit the vibration modes of chemical bonds in the synthesized amorphous ZrO2, Mn+ ZrO2, and Mn- ZrO2 catalysts. According to the literature, the vibration modes of important surface species such as –OH, H2O, CH, CO2, and CO3 2− are observed in the range of 4000–1000 cm−1, whereas the 1000–400 cm−1 range shows vibrational bands of the metal and oxygen bonding [49,50]. In amorphous ZrO2, a broad vibrational band in the range of 3461–3246 cm−1 is attributed to -OH stretching vibrations from intermolecular hydrogen bonds due to water. In the range of 1700–1000 cm−1, the vibrational band at 1621 cm−1 is attributed to -OH vibrations in the water, and the band at 1384 cm−1 corresponds to the stretching vibration of -OH bound to the surface of Zr (i.e., Zr-OH). A weak vibrational band at ∼1100 cm−1 is attributed to the Zr-OH stretching vibrations. These bands mostly represent the presence of different hydroxyl groups on the surface of Zr [49–51]. Metal addition to the support showed no significant changes in the surface and structure of the support ZrO2, as the Mn addition to the support showed similar vibrational bands in both methods. 3.1.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Mn 2p XPS spectra of the catalysts are depicted in Fig. 4 . The two peaks that appeared with binding energies of 640.9 and 653.3 eV are ascribed to the Mn2p3/2 and Mn2p1/2 transitions, respectively. A low intense BE peak at 639.1 eV is attributed to the presence of Mn0 [52,53]. Mn0 peak is observed in the physical mixing method and it is a consequence of direct Mn metal as a source of Mn for this catalyst. The deconvolution of the Mn2p3/2 peak resulted into a doublet peak and their binding energy values are 640.7 and 643.1 eV, which are commonly referred to as Mn2+ and Mn3+, respectively [54–57]. In both Mn catalysts, a similar doublet peak was observed indicating the co-existence of both MnO and Mn3O4 oxides. The areas of the deconvoluted peaks are considered to quantify the ratio of Mn2+/Mn3+. Mn2+/Mn3+ ratios in the catalysts are 1.57 and 0.55 for Mn+ZrO2 and Mn-ZrO2, respectively. The Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio of Mn+ZrO2 is relatively higher than that of Mn-ZrO2, which may be due to the high metal support interactions leading to an increase in the Mn3+ content in Mn-ZrO2 [58]. These values are in accordance with the XRD results, where we observed Mn metallic diffraction patterns in the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst due to the existence of Mn in its metallic/low oxidation states such as MnOx and MnO2-x. Fig. 5 shows the Zr 3d core level XPS spectra of ZrO2, Mn+ZrO2, and Mn-ZrO2 catalysts synthesized by various methods. The bands corresponding to zirconium oxide appearing at 180.8 and 183.0 eV are attributed to Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2, respectively. From the literature, the pure ZrO2 will show their spin-orbital splitting of Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 at 182.0 and 184.2 eV, respectively [59–61]. Whereas, in the present study the BE values are lower compared to the pure ZrO2. Low binding energy values signify the formation of Zr2+ and Zr4+. Deconvolution of the main peaks shows doublet peaks for Zr 3d5/2 with BE at 180.1, and 180.9 eV and Zr 3d3/2 with BE at 182.9 and 185.2 eV. These doublet peaks are representing the presence of Zr2+ (180.1 and 182.9 eV) and Zr4+ (180.9 and 185.2 eV) cations in samples. The addition of Mn by both methods showed the binding energy of peaks of Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 at 181.3 and 183.2, respectively. A clear observation points out that the BEs are increased with the addition of Mn, the increase in binding energy values indicates the enhanced surface interactions between metal and support. The deconvolution of these peaks resulted into two doublet peaks with BEs at 180.8, 181.7, 183.1 and 185.3 eV for the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst. The deconvolution of Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 in Mn-ZrO2 resulted in peaks at 180.6, 181.5, 183.0 and 185.5 eV. As observed in the support, the Mn addition also showed the presence of both Zr2+ and Zr4+ ions in the samples. The ratios of Zr2+/Zr4+ calculated with the area of deconvoluted peaks of Zr3d3/2 are 0.23, 10.47 and 11.27 for ZrO2, Mn+ZrO2 and Mn-ZrO2, respectively. The increased ratio of Zr2+/Zr4+ with the addition of Mn is related to the enhanced metal-support interactions leading to generating more defects in support, these defects are further enhanced with the co-precipitation method. These studies are in agreement with the XRD results, where the Mn metal peak disappeared in the co-precipitation method. The broad peak of the core level XPS spectrum of O 1 s is deconvoluted into triplet peaks at 528.3, 529.5, and 531.1 eV for all samples and depicted in Fig. 6 . These triplet peaks are ascribed to the Zr2+-O (528.3 eV), Zr4+-O of lattice oxygen (529.5 eV), and Zr-OH of a hydroxyl group (531.1 eV) on the surface [61–63]. The area of deconvoluted peaks is shown in Table S1, these values indicate the presence of Zr2+-O species with a high concentration in the co-precipitated catalyst (Mn-ZrO2). On the other hand, the areas of Zr4+-O and Zr-OH are high, this illustrates the presence of lattice oxygen and hydroxyl groups in ZrO2 support and physically mixed (Mn+ZrO2) catalysts. These results are in accordance with the FTIR results (OH vibrations are clearly observed in ZrO2 and Mn+ZrO2) and other XPS spectra, where the Zr2+/Zr4+ ratios are high in the co-precipitated catalyst (Mn-ZrO2). In Table S2, the relative atomic and weight surface concentration for the ZrO2 support, Mn+ ZrO2 and Mn- ZrO2 catalysts are calculated and reported. The amount of Mn in the catalysts is ∼6 wt.%. The atomic ratio of O:Zr is higher than 2, the slight increase in the atomic O concentration is due to the adsorbed carbonaceous oxides on the surface. 3.1.5 Scanning electron microscopy-energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Mn+ZrO2 and Mn-ZrO2 catalysts are depicted in Fig. 7 . All the catalysts showed nanoparticle morphology in SEM images (Fig. 7b&f). Both synthesis methods showed no considerable change in the morphology of the catalysts. The elemental mapping was carried out by using SEM-EDS (Fig. 7a&e are EDS images and Fig. 7c,d,g&h corresponding elemental mapping). The recorded images of elemental mapping illustrated that in the physically mixed catalyst Mn was also distributed uniformly on the support surface. 3.2 Catalytic activity Catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid was carried out at 225 °C for 4 h with 40 mg of catalyst, 0.25 M NaOH, and 0.4 M N2H4·H2O mixed and sealed and then pressurized with pure CO2 gas of an initial pressure of 10 bar. After the reaction, the resulting solution has two main products, formic acid (FA) and acetic acid (AA). Fig. 8 shows the comparison of catalysts with the products formed (FA & AA), for comparison purposes, the activity of Mn metal is also included. The catalysts composed of both Mn and ZrO2 showed promising activity toward the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid and acetic acid production. The catalyst synthesized by physical mixing (Mn+ZrO2) showed the highest activity of formic acid and acetic acid production with values of 41.6 and 13.9 mmol/gMn, respectively. Co-precipitated catalyst (Mn-ZrO2) showed less activity towards formic acid (25.9 mmol/gMn), while the production of acetic acid showed no considerable decrease (13.4 mmol/gMn). Among the catalysts studied, Mn metal showed poor activity towards hydrogenation of CO2 to FA and AA (0.83 and 0.83 mmol/gMn). No catalytic activity was recorded with ZrO2 support during the reaction carried out at 225 °C, but noticeable activity was observed with ZrO2 support conducted at 250 °C (Figure S1). According to Yao et al., the first step in the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid via hydrazine as a hydrogen source is the production of in-situ H2 from hydrazine on the metal surface [32]. Later, hydrogen reacts with CO2 adsorbed on the surface to produce formic acid. So, the first step of the decomposition of hydrazine to hydrogen is mainly carried out on the metal surface. In the XRD, the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst showed Mn metallic diffraction peaks, whereas the Mn-ZrO2 showed no diffraction peaks for Mn metal. In the XPS study, the Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio is relatively higher in the case of the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst, indicating the lower oxidation state/metallic nature is of considerably higher concentration in the physically mixed sample. So, the enhanced catalytic activity of Mn+ZrO2 is mainly due to the high existence of the metallic nature of Mn, thus enhancing the decomposition of hydrazine to hydrogen.Therefore, the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst was chosen for the optimization of reaction parameters by varying the reaction time, initial pressure of CO2 and weight of the catalyst. The reaction time plays a crucial role and shows a vital effect on the reactivity of CO2 hydrogenation to value-added products. So, the experiments were conducted by changing the reaction time from 2 to 6 h with an increment of 2 h by not changing the other reaction conditions such as catalyst weight: 40 mg (Mn+ZrO2), reaction temperature: 225 °C, 0.25 M NaOH, 1 mL of N2H4·H2O and 10 bar of CO2. Fig. 9 shows the change in product formation with the reaction time. The amount of hydrogenated product formed is increased with the increase in reaction time. Concentrations of formic acid and acetic acid in the outlet mixture increased from 11.9 to 73.6 (FA) and 8.9 to 60.4 (AA) mmol/gMn with the reaction time from 2 to 6 h, respectively. The increase in hydrogenated product formation with the reaction time is also observed by previous researchers [41,64,65]. According to Wang et al. [41] study of the CO2 hydrothermal reduction to acetic acid, with the increase in reaction time the yield of acetic acid is continuously increased after reaching maximum yield at 6 h, while further increase in reaction time showed no effect on the yield of acetic acid. The formation of AA is mainly due to the CC coupling of formate species and *CH2 intermediates. In another study, Chen et al. and Le et al. [64,65], CO2 hydrothermal reduction to formic acid with hydrazine is dependent on several reaction parameters. In their study, the formic acid yield is increased with an increase in reaction time. After 1 h of reaction time, the yield of formic acid reached maximum and then it decreased with an increase in reaction time. The decrease in the yield of formic acid production is due to the decomposition of formic acid into methane. By considering both studies, one can conclude that acetic acid formation is continuously increasing with the reaction time. The production of AA by hydrothermal reduction of CO2 is via the CC coupling of formate intermediate. So, the ratio of FA and AA are different after 4 h of reaction time where the produced FA is utilized in the reaction as an intermediate for the CC coupling to AA. On the other hand, the increase in temperature decreases the optimal reaction time. The previous works of hydrothermal reduction of CO2 to formic acid were carried out at 250 °C and above and achieved the highest formic acid yield with 60 and 120 min of reaction time depending on the catalysts used [23,29,32]. Here, the reaction was carried out at 225 °C, therefore the reaction time is longer than in the previous reports. In order to claim the statement that the increase in reaction temperature also decreases the optimal reaction time, the reaction was conducted at 250 °C for 2 h and the results are depicted in Figure S1. The reaction at 250 °C for 2 h showed promising activity with a high amount of both hydrogenated products (FA and AA) for all the catalysts. Catalyst activity tests with different CO2 initial pressures were examined for the hydrogenation of CO2 to FA and AA (Fig. 10 ). The other reaction parameters were unchanged i.e., 40 mg of catalyst, 0.25 M of NaOH, 1 mL of N2H4·H2O and 225 °C for 6 h. The increase in CO2 pressure from 10 to 20 bar shows no considerable change in the formation of hydrogenated products. Further, increase in CO2 pressure from 20 to 40 bar affected the formic acid production, so it constantly decreased from 73.3 to 58.5 mmol/gMn, respectively. A similar trend was observed in the case of acetic acid production with an increase in CO2 pressure. This trend is in collaboration with the previous literature reports, where the decrease of hydrogenated products with an increase in the amount of CO2 reactant is observed due to the formation of Na2CO3 species in the reaction mixture [25,29]. The dissolution of CO2 into NaOH solution is effectively increased with the increase of pH of the solution, but the high alkaline solution can promote the formation of Na2CO3 in the solution which decreases the formic acid formation. The increase in CO2 pressure in this study might also promote the formation of highly alkali carbonate such as Na2CO3, thus formic and acetic acid production decreased. Catalyst activity tests with change in weight of the catalyst were conducted with 10, 20, 40, and 60 mg of catalyst, 0.25 M of NaOH, 0.4 M of N2H4·H2O and CO2 gas with an initial pressure of 10 bar, and the results are depicted in Fig. 11 . The increase in catalyst weight from 10 to 40 mg increased the formation of formic and acetic acid from 0.459 to 0.736 (FA) and 0.281 to 0.604 (AA) µmol/min. With further increase in the weight of the catalyst, the amounts of formic and acetic acid are decreased to 0.425 (FA) and 0.139 (AA) µmol/min. The decrease in the hydrogenation products is due to the decomposition of the formic and acetic acids. The decrease in formic acid formation is also observed by the previous researchers and it is due to the decomposition of formic acid [32]. 3.3 Structure-activity relationship XRD of ZrO2 showed two broad peaks illustrating that the support is in an amorphous phase. The addition of Mn in both methods shows no effect on the crystallinity of the support. However, the addition of Mn by physical method showed Mn diffraction peaks indicating that at least part of the Mn is kept in metallic form in the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst. On the other hand, no Mn diffraction peaks are observed for the Mn-ZrO2 catalyst. Amorphous ZrO2 with a high specific surface area showed a decrease in surface area by the physical mixing method attributed to the surface coverage of metal. The XPS study confirmed that the majority of metal in the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst is stabilized in metallic nature. The surface covering of metallic Mn on the support in the physical mixing method leads to an increase in the Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio in the Mn+ZrO2 catalyst. The lower oxidation/metallic nature Mn shows a beneficial effect on the catalytic activity. As mentioned earlier, the first step in CO2 hydrogenation via an indirect hydrogen source is to produce hydrogen from an indirect hydrogen source. The conversion of hydrazine (indirect hydrogen source) to hydrogen occurs at the metal surface. Thus, a catalyst with an enhanced metallic surface (high Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio) leads to an improvement in the catalytic conversion of CO2 to formic and acetic acid. Mn+ZrO2 thus shows improved catalytic activity compared to Mn-ZrO2. 4 Conclusions In summary, amorphous ZrO2 and Mn-modified ZrO2 catalysts were synthesized by two methods. All of these materials exhibited high specific surface area, and the surface area of the catalyst increased with the increase of the pore volume by the co-precipitation method. The XRD study showed the presence of metallic Mn peaks in the case of the physically mixed catalyst. The XPS study revealed that the stabilization of Mn in its metallic/lower oxidation state is achieved by the physical mixing method, i.e., the Mn2+/Mn3+ ratio is high in the case of Mn+ZrO2 compared to the Mn-ZrO2 catalyst. Indeed, the presence of Mn in its lower oxidation state/ metallic form helps to enhance the decomposition of hydrazine to hydrogen, which promotes the formation of hydrogenated products. The optimization studies showed that reaction time and CO2 partial pressure play an important role in the production of formic acid and acetic acid. The highest values of hydrogenated products formed were 73.3 and 58.5 mmol/gMn formic acid and acetic acid, respectively. coredata.dc:description: Amorphous ZrO2 and Mn addition to ZrO2 catalysts were studied for CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid and acetic acid via an indirect hydrogen source, i.e., hydrazine monohydrate. The amorphous ZrO2 was synthesized by the precipitation method and the Mn addition was carried out by two different methods, namely, the physical mixing method (Mn+ZrO2) and the co-precipitation method (Mn-ZrO2). The XRD and XPS results show that the enhanced metal-support interaction in the co-precipitation method leads to the stabilization of Mn in its higher oxidation state. The physical mixing method leads to the stabilization of Mn in its lower oxidation state and/or metallic form, which improves hydrogen production from hydrazine and thus CO2 hydrogenation. Optimization of reaction parameters was investigated with changes in reaction conditions such as reaction time, CO2 pressure and catalyst weight.
coredata.dc:title: Effective production of formic and acetic acid via CO2 hydrogenation with hydrazine by using ZrO2 catalysts
